title: Intrinsically Safe Grounding Systems and Global Grounding Systems
abstract: This paper introduces a characterization of grounding systems (GSs) and defines their condition of “conventionally safe” and “intrinsically safe.” A single GS and a set of GSs are intrinsically safe if they guarantee touch/step voltages permanently permissible for an assigned ground fault value. A new definition of global grounding systems (GGSs) is proposed, revising that offered by the Standards IEC 61936-1/EN 50522. A safety criterion, useful for urban and industrial areas with reduced accessibility, allows identifying the safety zone of influence, and the intrinsically safe condition of a single GS and of a GGS, constituted by a set of interconnected single GSs.

motivations: Existing grounding systems may not guarantee permanently permissible touch/step voltages for assigned ground fault values, posing safety risks.
Current standards for global grounding systems may be inadequate or outdated, requiring revision for improved safety.
objectives: Characterize and define the conditions for 'conventionally safe' and 'intrinsically safe' grounding systems.
Propose a revised definition of global grounding systems (GGSs) for enhanced safety.
Establish a safety criterion for identifying the safety zone of influence and ensuring the intrinsically safe condition of grounding systems.
methods: Develop a new definition of global grounding systems, revising existing standards such as IEC 61936-1/EN 50522.
Introduce a safety criterion for evaluating the safety of grounding systems, particularly in urban and industrial areas with reduced accessibility.
results: Ensure permanently permissible touch/step voltages for assigned ground fault values, enhancing the safety of grounding systems.
Provide a revised framework for designing and evaluating global grounding systems, promoting improved safety in urban and industrial areas.
